newsitem.title: UK: Copper trades at 11-1/2 LME high, seen pushing up.
newsitem.headline: Copper trades at 11-1/2 LME high, seen pushing up.

text.p: Copper prices broke above the $2,440 a tonne level during early Thursday London Metal Exchange (LME) trading - the highest the market has been since early June 1996.
Three months was at $2,447/50 a tonne, well above the $2,414 Wednesday official close, spurred higher by speculative investment fund buying overnight, traders said.
"It (copper) had been trying to clear $2,440 all morning, but people were bit wary because there has been some forward sales recently," a LME trader said.
However, once $2,440 was conclusively hurdled, the market sped higher to near $2,460 as pre-programmed buy orders were triggered, traders added.

The stimulus for current strength in copper was provided by a 3,225-tonne drop in LME warehouse stocks of metal. This trend was likely to continue, as nearby supplies are thin on the ground, analysts said.
Copper consumption has been good so far this year, which is helping to offset increased mine supply, analysts said.
